aligning diverse modal inputs into the language embedding space. This addresses
a significant gap in existing literature. We propose a classification framework
for MLLMs based on three key dimensions. First, we examine architectural
strategies for modality integration. This includes both the specific
integration mechanisms and the fusion level. Second, we categorize
representation learning techniques as either joint or coordinate
representations. Third, we analyze training paradigms, including training
strategies and objective functions. By examining 125 MLLMs developed between
2021 and 2025, we identify emerging patterns in the field. Our taxonomy
provides researchers with a structured overview of current integration
techniques. These insights aim to guide the development of more robust
multimodal integration strategies for future models built on pre-trained
foundations.

AI.tldr: Survey of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) focusing on methods for input transformation and alignment to language embeddings.
AI.motivation: To systematically understand the connections between different modalities and the language backbone in MLLMs.
AI.method: Analysis and classification framework for MLLMs based on architectural strategies, representation learning techniques, and training paradigms, examining 125 MLLMs.
AI.result: Identification of patterns in MLLM integration approaches and a structured taxonomy of current methods.
AI.conclusion: The taxonomy can guide future research in developing robust multimodal integration strategies for pre-trained models.
key_contributions: Introduces a classification framework for MLLMs
Analyzes integration strategies and representation learning
Surveys 125 MLLMs to identify emerging patterns

title: Dissecting Logical Reasoning in LLMs: A Fine-Grained Evaluation and Supervision Study
summary:
Logical reasoning is a core capability for many applications of large
language models (LLMs), yet existing benchmarks often rely solely on
final-answer accuracy, failing to capture the quality and structure of the
reasoning process. We propose FineLogic, a fine-grained evaluation framework
that assesses logical reasoning across three dimensions: overall benchmark
accuracy, stepwise soundness, and representation-level alignment. In addition,
to better understand how reasoning capabilities emerge, we conduct a
comprehensive study on the effects of supervision format during fine-tuning. We
construct four supervision styles (one natural language and three symbolic
variants) and train LLMs under each. Our findings reveal that natural language
supervision yields strong generalization even on out-of-distribution and
long-context tasks, while symbolic reasoning styles promote more structurally
sound and atomic inference chains. Further, our representation-level probing
shows that fine-tuning primarily improves reasoning behaviors through
step-by-step generation, rather than enhancing shortcut prediction or
internalized correctness. Together, our framework and analysis provide a more
rigorous and interpretable lens for evaluating and improving logical reasoning
in LLMs.

AI.tldr: FineLogic is a framework for evaluating logical reasoning in large language models (LLMs), emphasizing the importance of stepwise soundness and representation alignment alongside accuracy.
AI.motivation: To provide a comprehensive evaluation of logical reasoning in LLMs that goes beyond final-answer accuracy.
AI.method: FineLogic evaluates reasoning across overall benchmark accuracy, stepwise soundness, and representation-level alignment, with studies on supervision formats during fine-tuning.
AI.result: Natural language supervision leads to better generalization, while symbolic reasoning enhances inference structures; fine-tuning improves reasoning through step-by-step generation.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework offers a more rigorous and interpretable method for assessing and enhancing reasoning in LLMs.
key_contributions: Introduction of FineLogic for evaluating logical reasoning in LLMs
Insights on the effectiveness of different supervision styles during fine-tuning
Demonstrated importance of stepwise reasoning over simple correctness in LLMs

title: Design of intelligent proofreading system for English translation based on CNN and BERT
summary:
Since automatic translations can contain errors that require substantial
human post-editing, machine translation proofreading is essential for improving
quality. This paper proposes a novel hybrid approach for robust proofreading
that combines convolutional neural networks (CNN) with Bidirectional Encoder
Representations from Transformers (BERT). In order to extract semantic
information from phrases and expressions, CNN uses a variety of convolution
kernel filters to capture local n-gram patterns. In the meanwhile, BERT creates
context-rich representations of whole sequences by utilizing stacked
bidirectional transformer encoders. Using BERT's attention processes, the
integrated error detection component relates tokens to spot translation
irregularities including word order problems and omissions. The correction
module then uses parallel English-German alignment and GRU decoder models in
conjunction with translation memory to propose logical modifications that
maintain original meaning. A unified end-to-end training process optimized for
post-editing performance is applied to the whole pipeline. The multi-domain
collection of WMT and the conversational dialogues of Open-Subtitles are two of
the English-German parallel corpora used to train the model. Multiple loss
functions supervise detection and correction capabilities. Experiments attain a
90% accuracy, 89.37% F1, and 16.24% MSE, exceeding recent proofreading
techniques by over 10% overall. Comparative benchmarking demonstrates
state-of-the-art performance in identifying and coherently rectifying
mistranslations and omissions.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a hybrid approach for proofreading machine translations using CNN and BERT to enhance quality through error detection and correction.
AI.motivation: Automatic translations often contain errors requiring substantial post-editing; hence, effective proofreading is essential for quality improvement.
AI.method: The approach combines convolutional neural networks (CNN) for local n-gram pattern detection with BERT for context-rich sequence representations. It uses an integrated error detection component and a correction module leveraging translation memory and GRU decoders, trained through a unified end-to-end process.
AI.result: Experiments achieved a 90% accuracy, 89.37% F1, and 16.24% MSE, surpassing recent proofreading techniques by over 10%.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hybrid model demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in identifying and correcting mistranslations and omissions.
key_contributions: Hybrid proofreading approach combining CNN and BERT
Unified end-to-end training for post-editing performance
State-of-the-art performance benchmarks

title: Evaluating Vision-Language and Large Language Models for Automated Student Assessment in Indonesian Classrooms
summary:
Although vision-language and large language models (VLM and LLM) offer
promising opportunities for AI-driven educational assessment, their
effectiveness in real-world classroom settings, particularly in
underrepresented educational contexts, remains underexplored. In this study, we
evaluated the performance of a state-of-the-art VLM and several LLMs on 646
handwritten exam responses from grade 4 students in six Indonesian schools,
covering two subjects: Mathematics and English. These sheets contain more than
14K student answers that span multiple choice, short answer, and essay
questions. Assessment tasks include grading these responses and generating
personalized feedback. Our findings show that the VLM often struggles to
accurately recognize student handwriting, leading to error propagation in
downstream LLM grading. Nevertheless, LLM-generated feedback retains some
utility, even when derived from imperfect input, although limitations in
personalization and contextual relevance persist.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates the effectiveness of vision-language and large language models in grading handwritten exam responses of grade 4 students in Indonesia.
AI.motivation: To explore real-world applications of AI-driven educational assessment using VLM and LLM in underrepresented educational contexts.
AI.method: Evaluated a state-of-the-art VLM and several LLMs on 646 handwritten exam responses across two subjects, Mathematics and English, from six Indonesian schools.
AI.result: The VLM struggled with recognizing handwriting accurately, leading to error propagation in LLM grading; however, LLM-generated feedback was somewhat useful despite limitations.
AI.conclusion: While LLMs can produce useful feedback, challenges in handwriting recognition and personalization need to be addressed for better application in educational settings.
key_contributions: Evaluation of VLM and LLM performance in a real-world educational context
Insights into challenges of handwriting recognition in grading
Analysis of LLM feedback utility despite input imperfections
AI.limitations: Struggles with handwriting recognition and limitations in personalization and contextual relevance of feedback.

title: A Reasoning-Based Approach to Cryptic Crossword Clue Solving
comment: 9 page paper plus Appendices. Accepted to ICML 2025
summary:
Cryptic crossword clues are challenging language tasks for which new test
sets are released daily by major newspapers on a global basis. Each cryptic
clue contains both the definition of the answer to be placed in the crossword
grid (in common with regular crosswords), and 'wordplay' that proves that the
answer is correct (i.e. a human solver can be confident that an answer is
correct without needing crossing words as confirmation). This work describes an
LLM-based reasoning system built from open-licensed components that solves
cryptic clues by (i) hypothesising answers; (ii) proposing wordplay
explanations; and (iii) using a verifier system that operates on codified
reasoning steps. Overall, this system establishes a new state-of-the-art
performance on the challenging Cryptonite dataset of clues from The Times and
The Telegraph newspapers in the UK. Because each proved solution is expressed
in Python, interpretable wordplay reasoning for proven answers is available for
inspection.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an LLM-based system for solving cryptic crossword clues by hypothesizing answers and providing wordplay explanations, achieving state-of-the-art results on a benchmark dataset.
AI.motivation: Cryptic crossword clues are complex language tasks that require skilled reasoning, and there is a need for improved automated solutions to assist in solving them.
AI.method: The proposed system hypothesizes potential answers, generates corresponding wordplay explanations, and employs a verification mechanism that utilizes codified reasoning steps.
AI.result: The system demonstrates a new state-of-the-art performance on the Cryptonite dataset, indicating significant advancements in automated reasoning for cryptic clues.
AI.conclusion: This research establishes a foundation for enhanced interpretation of crossword clues through LLMs, with the systematic reasoning steps made accessible in Python.
key_contributions: LLM-based reasoning system for cryptic crossword clues
Achieved state-of-the-art performance on the Cryptonite dataset
Provides interpretable wordplay reasoning for solutions expressed in Python

title: Joint Evaluation of Answer and Reasoning Consistency for Hallucination Detection in Large Reasoning Models
summary:
Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) extend large language models with explicit,
multi-step reasoning traces to enhance transparency and performance on complex
tasks. However, these reasoning traces can be redundant or logically
inconsistent, making them a new source of hallucination that is difficult to
detect. Existing hallucination detection methods focus primarily on
answer-level uncertainty and often fail to detect hallucinations or logical
inconsistencies arising from the model's reasoning trace. This oversight is
particularly problematic for LRMs, where the explicit thinking trace is not
only an important support to the model's decision-making process but also a key
source of potential hallucination. To this end, we propose RACE (Reasoning and
Answer Consistency Evaluation), a novel framework specifically tailored for
hallucination detection in LRMs. RACE operates by extracting essential
reasoning steps and computing four diagnostic signals: inter-sample consistency
of reasoning traces, entropy-based answer uncertainty, semantic alignment
between reasoning and answers, and internal coherence of reasoning. This joint
analysis enables fine-grained hallucination detection even when the final
answer appears correct. Experiments across datasets and different LLMs
demonstrate that RACE outperforms existing hallucination detection baselines,
offering a robust and generalizable solution for evaluating LRMs. Our code is
available at: https://github.com/bebr2/RACE.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces RACE, a framework for detecting hallucinations in Large Reasoning Models by analyzing their explicit reasoning traces.
AI.motivation: To address the issue of redundancy and logical inconsistencies in reasoning traces of Large Reasoning Models (LRMs), which can lead to hallucinations.
AI.method: RACE extracts essential reasoning steps and computes four diagnostic signals: inter-sample consistency of reasoning traces, entropy-based answer uncertainty, semantic alignment between reasoning and answers, and internal coherence of reasoning.
AI.result: RACE outperforms existing hallucination detection methods, providing a robust solution for evaluating LRMs with a focus on fine-grained hallucination detection.
AI.conclusion: RACE offers significant improvements in hallucination detection for LRMs, making it a valuable tool for ensuring the reliability of complex AI systems.
key_contributions: Introduction of the RACE framework for hallucination detection in LRMs.
Analysis of reasoning traces with multiple diagnostic signals.
Empirical validation showing superior performance compared to existing methods.

title: MockConf: A Student Interpretation Dataset: Analysis, Word- and Span-level Alignment and Baselines
summary:
In simultaneous interpreting, an interpreter renders a source speech into
another language with a very short lag, much sooner than sentences are
finished. In order to understand and later reproduce this dynamic and complex
task automatically, we need dedicated datasets and tools for analysis,
monitoring, and evaluation, such as parallel speech corpora, and tools for
their automatic annotation. Existing parallel corpora of translated texts and
associated alignment algorithms hardly fill this gap, as they fail to model
long-range interactions between speech segments or specific types of
divergences (e.g., shortening, simplification, functional generalization)
between the original and interpreted speeches. In this work, we introduce
MockConf, a student interpreting dataset that was collected from Mock
Conferences run as part of the students' curriculum. This dataset contains 7
hours of recordings in 5 European languages, transcribed and aligned at the
level of spans and words. We further implement and release InterAlign, a modern
web-based annotation tool for parallel word and span annotations on long
inputs, suitable for aligning simultaneous interpreting. We propose metrics for
the evaluation and a baseline for automatic alignment. Dataset and tools are
released to the community.

AI.tldr: Presentation of MockConf, a new dataset for analyzing simultaneous interpreting, alongside a web-based tool for annotations.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of dedicated datasets and tools for analyzing and evaluating simultaneous interpreting, which is a complex task involving rendering source speeches with minimal delay.
AI.method: Introduction of MockConf, a dataset with 7 hours of multilingual recordings, and the development of InterAlign, a web-based tool for aligning and annotating these recordings.
AI.result: MockConf dataset includes transcriptions aligned by spans and words and provides metrics for evaluation along with a baseline for automatic alignment.
AI.conclusion: MockConf and InterAlign offer new resources for the research community to facilitate the study of simultaneous interpreting.
key_contributions: Introduction of the MockConf dataset with detailed annotations for interpreting tasks.
Development of InterAlign tool for modern web-based parallel annotations.
Proposition of new evaluation metrics and baseline for automatic alignment.

title: Multiple-Choice Question Generation Using Large Language Models: Methodology and Educator Insights
comment:
Copyright ACM 2024. This is the author's version of the work. It is
  posted here for your personal use. Not for redistribution. The definitive
  Version of Record was published in Adjunct Proceedings of the 32nd ACM
  Conference on User Modeling, Adaptation and Personalization (UMAP Adjunct
  '24), http://dx.doi.org/10.1145/3631700.3665233
summary:
Integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) in educational settings has brought
new learning approaches, transforming the practices of both students and
educators. Among the various technologies driving this transformation, Large
Language Models (LLMs) have emerged as powerful tools for creating educational
materials and question answering, but there are still space for new
applications. Educators commonly use Multiple-Choice Questions (MCQs) to assess
student knowledge, but manually generating these questions is
resource-intensive and requires significant time and cognitive effort. In our
opinion, LLMs offer a promising solution to these challenges. This paper
presents a novel comparative analysis of three widely known LLMs - Llama 2,
Mistral, and GPT-3.5 - to explore their potential for creating informative and
challenging MCQs. In our approach, we do not rely on the knowledge of the LLM,
but we inject the knowledge into the prompt to contrast the hallucinations,
giving the educators control over the test's source text, too. Our experiment
involving 21 educators shows that GPT-3.5 generates the most effective MCQs
across several known metrics. Additionally, it shows that there is still some
reluctance to adopt AI in the educational field. This study sheds light on the
potential of LLMs to generate MCQs and improve the educational experience,
providing valuable insights for the future.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the effectiveness of three LLMs in generating Multiple-Choice Questions (MCQs) for educational purposes, highlighting GPT-3.5's superiority and addressing AI adoption reluctance among educators.
AI.motivation: To explore the potential of LLMs in generating MCQs, making the assessment process more efficient for educators.
AI.method: A comparative analysis of Llama 2, Mistral, and GPT-3.5 was conducted by injecting knowledge into prompts and evaluating the generated MCQs through metrics with feedback from 21 educators.
AI.result: GPT-3.5 was found to generate the most effective MCQs according to several metrics, reflecting its potential in educational applications.
AI.conclusion: LLMs can significantly improve the generation of MCQs, enhancing the educational experience, though educators still show reluctance towards AI integration.
key_contributions: Comparative analysis of Llama 2, Mistral, and GPT-3.5 for MCQ generation.
Emphasizing the method of injecting knowledge into prompts for better control.
Insights into educator reluctance regarding AI adoption in education.
AI.limitations: The study relies on the effectiveness of the LLMs for generating MCQs but does not address wider implications of AI in education.

title: Prompting LLMs: Length Control for Isometric Machine Translation
summary:
In this study, we explore the effectiveness of isometric machine translation
across multiple language pairs (En$\to$De, En$\to$Fr, and En$\to$Es) under the
conditions of the IWSLT Isometric Shared Task 2022. Using eight open-source
large language models (LLMs) of varying sizes, we investigate how different
prompting strategies, varying numbers of few-shot examples, and demonstration
selection influence translation quality and length control. We discover that
the phrasing of instructions, when aligned with the properties of the provided
demonstrations, plays a crucial role in controlling the output length. Our
experiments show that LLMs tend to produce shorter translations only when
presented with extreme examples, while isometric demonstrations often lead to
the models disregarding length constraints. While few-shot prompting generally
enhances translation quality, further improvements are marginal across 5, 10,
and 20-shot settings. Finally, considering multiple outputs allows to notably
improve overall tradeoff between the length and quality, yielding
state-of-the-art performance for some language pairs.

AI.tldr: This study investigates the effectiveness of isometric machine translation using various large language models across multiple language pairs, revealing that prompt design impacts translation quality and length control significantly.
AI.motivation: To explore how isometric machine translation performs under specific conditions and identify strategies that optimize translation quality and length control for language pairs.
AI.method: The study utilizes eight open-source large language models and tests different prompting strategies with varying numbers of few-shot examples while implementing isometric demonstrations for translation tasks.
AI.result: The findings suggest that proper instruction phrasing and extreme examples are necessary to control output length. Few-shot prompting improves translation quality but has diminishing returns, and considering multiple outputs is beneficial for achieving better quality-length tradeoffs.
AI.conclusion: Optimizing prompt strategies and instruction phrasing can significantly enhance isometric machine translation, contributing to state-of-the-art results for certain language pairs.
key_contributions: Demonstrated the impact of prompt design on length control and translation quality.
Identified that few-shot approaches lead to marginal improvements in translation.
Showed that using multiple outputs improves the balance between quality and length in translation.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Linguistic Knowledge in Pretrained Language Models: A Case Study of Universal Dependencies
summary:
Universal Dependencies (UD), while widely regarded as the most successful
linguistic framework for cross-lingual syntactic representation, remains
underexplored in terms of its effectiveness. This paper addresses this gap by
integrating UD into pretrained language models and assesses if UD can improve
their performance on a cross-lingual adversarial paraphrase identification
task. Experimental results show that incorporation of UD yields significant
improvements in accuracy and $F_1$ scores, with average gains of 3.85\% and
6.08\% respectively. These enhancements reduce the performance gap between
pretrained models and large language models in some language pairs, and even
outperform the latter in some others. Furthermore, the UD-based similarity
score between a given language and English is positively correlated to the
performance of models in that language. Both findings highlight the validity
and potential of UD in out-of-domain tasks.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the effectiveness of Universal Dependencies (UD) integrated into pretrained language models for cross-lingual paraphrase identification, showing significant performance improvements.
AI.motivation: To address the gap in understanding the effectiveness of Universal Dependencies (UD) in linguistic representation and its impact on pretrained language models in cross-lingual tasks.
AI.method: The study integrates Universal Dependencies into pretrained language models and evaluates their performance on a cross-lingual adversarial paraphrase identification task.
AI.result: Incorporating UD resulted in significant gains in accuracy (3.85%) and F1 scores (6.08%), reducing the performance gap with large language models in several language pairs and sometimes outperforming them.
AI.conclusion: The findings confirm the validity of integrating UD for enhancing model performance in out-of-domain tasks and establishing a correlation between UD similarity scores and model performance.
key_contributions: Integration of UD into pretrained language models
Demonstrated improvements in accuracy and F1 scores
Correlation between UD similarity scores and model performance

title: ICPC-Eval: Probing the Frontiers of LLM Reasoning with Competitive Programming Contests
summary:
With the significant progress of large reasoning models in complex coding and
reasoning tasks, existing benchmarks, like LiveCodeBench and CodeElo, are
insufficient to evaluate the coding capabilities of large language models
(LLMs) in real competition environments. Moreover, current evaluation metrics
such as Pass@K fail to capture the reflective abilities of reasoning models. To
address these challenges, we propose \textbf{ICPC-Eval}, a top-level
competitive coding benchmark designed to probing the frontiers of LLM
reasoning. ICPC-Eval includes 118 carefully curated problems from 11 recent
ICPC contests held in various regions of the world, offering three key
contributions: 1) A challenging realistic ICPC competition scenario, featuring
a problem type and difficulty distribution consistent with actual contests. 2)
A robust test case generation method and a corresponding local evaluation
toolkit, enabling efficient and accurate local evaluation. 3) An effective
test-time scaling evaluation metric, Refine@K, which allows iterative repair of
solutions based on execution feedback. The results underscore the significant
challenge in evaluating complex reasoning abilities: top-tier reasoning models
like DeepSeek-R1 often rely on multi-turn code feedback to fully unlock their
in-context reasoning potential when compared to non-reasoning counterparts.
Furthermore, despite recent advancements in code generation, these models still
lag behind top-performing human teams. We release the benchmark at:
https://github.com/RUCAIBox/Slow_Thinking_with_LLMs

AI.tldr: ICPC-Eval is a new competitive coding benchmark specifically designed to evaluate the reasoning and coding capabilities of large language models (LLMs) in realistic contest scenarios.
AI.motivation: The need for improved benchmarks and metrics for evaluating LLMs' coding and reasoning abilities due to inadequacies in existing tools and methods.
AI.method: ICPC-Eval features 118 curated problems from recent ICPC contests, a test case generation method, a local evaluation toolkit, and the introduction of the Refine@K metric for better evaluation.
AI.result: Evaluation showed that top-tier reasoning models like DeepSeek-R1 perform significantly better with multi-turn feedback, but still fall short compared to human teams.
AI.conclusion: While LLMs show promise, they require iterative feedback to achieve their potential and currently do not outperform the best human teams in coding competitions.
key_contributions: Realistic ICPC competition scenario with actual contest problems
Robust test case generation and evaluation toolkit
New metric Refine@K for iterative solution improvement
AI.limitations: The benchmark may not cover all possible coding scenarios or problem types that would be encountered in diverse coding environments.

title: Verbose ListOps (VLO): Beyond Long Context -- Unmasking LLM's Reasoning Blind Spots
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs), whilst great at extracting facts from text,
struggle with nested narrative reasoning. Existing long context and multi-hop
QA benchmarks inadequately test this, lacking realistic distractors or failing
to decouple context length from reasoning complexity, masking a fundamental LLM
limitation. We introduce Verbose ListOps, a novel benchmark that
programmatically transposes ListOps computations into lengthy, coherent
stories. This uniquely forces internal computation and state management of
nested reasoning problems by withholding intermediate results, and offers
fine-grained controls for both narrative size \emph{and} reasoning difficulty.
Whilst benchmarks like LongReason (2025) advance approaches for synthetically
expanding the context size of multi-hop QA problems, Verbose ListOps pinpoints
a specific LLM vulnerability: difficulty in state management for nested
sub-reasoning amongst semantically-relevant, distracting narrative. Our
experiments show that leading LLMs (e.g., OpenAI o4, Gemini 2.5 Pro) collapse
in performance on Verbose ListOps at modest (~10k token) narrative lengths,
despite effortlessly solving raw ListOps equations. Addressing this failure is
paramount for real-world text interpretation which requires identifying key
reasoning points, tracking conceptual intermediate results, and filtering
irrelevant information. Verbose ListOps, and its extensible generation
framework thus enables targeted reasoning enhancements beyond mere
context-window expansion; a critical step to automating the world's knowledge
work.

AI.tldr: Introducing Verbose ListOps, a benchmark aimed at evaluating LLMs' performance in nested narrative reasoning and state management.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks inadequately test LLMs' capabilities in nested reasoning and fail to address their limitations in handling context length and reasoning complexity.
AI.method: The study introduces Verbose ListOps, which transposes ListOps computations into lengthy narratives, testing LLMs on their state management abilities and narrative understanding.
AI.result: Experiments show that leading LLMs significantly decline in performance on Verbose ListOps at moderate narrative lengths, highlighting their struggles with nested reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Addressing LLM failures in nested reasoning is crucial for real-world text interpretation, and Verbose ListOps provides a framework for achieving targeted reasoning enhancements.
key_contributions: Introduction of Verbose ListOps as a benchmark for nested reasoning
Identification of LLM vulnerabilities in state management
Development of a framework enabling granular control over narrative size and reasoning difficulty.

title: A Practitioner's Guide to Building ASR Models for Low-Resource Languages: A Case Study on Scottish Gaelic
summary:
An effective approach to the development of ASR systems for low-resource
languages is to fine-tune an existing multilingual end-to-end model. When the
original model has been trained on large quantities of data from many
languages, fine-tuning can be effective with limited training data, even when
the language in question was not present in the original training data. The
fine-tuning approach has been encouraged by the availability of public-domain
E2E models and is widely believed to lead to state-of-the-art results. This
paper, however, challenges that belief. We show that an approach combining
hybrid HMMs with self-supervised models can yield substantially better
performance with limited training data. This combination allows better
utilisation of all available speech and text data through continued
self-supervised pre-training and semi-supervised training. We benchmark our
approach on Scottish Gaelic, achieving WER reductions of 32% relative over our
best fine-tuned Whisper model.

AI.tldr: This paper challenges the effectiveness of fine-tuning multilingual ASR models for low-resource languages and presents a hybrid HMM and self-supervised model approach that significantly improves performance with limited data.
AI.motivation: There is a widespread belief that fine-tuning existing multilingual ASR models leads to state-of-the-art results for low-resource languages, but this paper argues against that notion.
AI.method: The authors propose a hybrid model combining HMMs with self-supervised learning techniques and semi-supervised training to utilize available speech and text data more effectively.
AI.result: The proposed method results in a 32% relative reduction in Word Error Rate (WER) on Scottish Gaelic compared to the best fine-tuned Whisper model.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest that hybrid HMMs combined with self-supervised models outperform traditional fine-tuning methods in developing ASR systems for low-resource languages.
key_contributions: Introduction of a hybrid HMM and self-supervised learning approach for ASR
Demonstrated substantial performance improvements on Scottish Gaelic
Provided evidence against the effectiveness of fine-tuning for low-resource ASR

title: Simulating LLM-to-LLM Tutoring for Multilingual Math Feedback
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated the ability to generate
formative feedback and instructional hints in English, making them increasingly
relevant for AI-assisted education. However, their ability to provide effective
instructional support across different languages, especially for mathematically
grounded reasoning tasks, remains largely unexamined. In this work, we present
the first large-scale simulation of multilingual tutor-student interactions
using LLMs. A stronger model plays the role of the tutor, generating feedback
in the form of hints, while a weaker model simulates the student. We explore
352 experimental settings across 11 typologically diverse languages, four
state-of-the-art LLMs, and multiple prompting strategies to assess whether
language-specific feedback leads to measurable learning gains. Our study
examines how student input language, teacher feedback language, model choice,
and language resource level jointly influence performance. Results show that
multilingual hints can significantly improve learning outcomes, particularly in
low-resource languages when feedback is aligned with the student's native
language. These findings offer practical insights for developing multilingual,
LLM-based educational tools that are both effective and inclusive.

AI.tldr: This study investigates the effectiveness of multilingual LLMs in providing instructional feedback for education, highlighting their impact on learning outcomes across diverse languages.
AI.motivation: To examine the effectiveness of LLMs in giving multilingual instructional feedback and support for mathematically grounded reasoning tasks, particularly for low-resource languages.
AI.method: Large-scale simulation of tutor-student interactions using LLMs, with one LLM acting as the tutor providing hints and another as the student, across 352 experimental settings involving 11 languages and multiple prompting strategies.
AI.result: Multilingual instructional hints significantly improved learning outcomes, especially in low-resource languages when feedback was aligned with the student's native language.
AI.conclusion: Aligning feedback language with the student's input language enhances learning, providing insights for the development of effective multilingual educational tools.
key_contributions: First large-scale simulation of multilingual LLM tutor-student interactions
Demonstrated effectiveness of language-aligned feedback in low-resource languages
Insights for creating inclusive, multilingual educational tools

title: ConECT Dataset: Overcoming Data Scarcity in Context-Aware E-Commerce MT
comment:
Accepted at ACL 2025 (The 63rd Annual Meeting of the Association for
  Computational Linguistics)
summary:
Neural Machine Translation (NMT) has improved translation by using
Transformer-based models, but it still struggles with word ambiguity and
context. This problem is especially important in domain-specific applications,
which often have problems with unclear sentences or poor data quality. Our
research explores how adding information to models can improve translations in
the context of e-commerce data. To this end we create ConECT -- a new
Czech-to-Polish e-commerce product translation dataset coupled with images and
product metadata consisting of 11,400 sentence pairs. We then investigate and
compare different methods that are applicable to context-aware translation. We
test a vision-language model (VLM), finding that visual context aids
translation quality. Additionally, we explore the incorporation of contextual
information into text-to-text models, such as the product's category path or
image descriptions. The results of our study demonstrate that the incorporation
of contextual information leads to an improvement in the quality of machine
translation. We make the new dataset publicly available.

AI.tldr: This paper presents ConECT, a dataset for enhancing context-aware neural machine translation in e-commerce, demonstrating that contextual information improves translation quality.
AI.motivation: Neural Machine Translation (NMT) faces challenges with word ambiguity and context, particularly in domain-specific applications. The research aims to address these issues specifically in e-commerce data.
AI.method: The authors create a new Czech-to-Polish e-commerce translation dataset, ConECT, consisting of 11,400 sentence pairs, along with images and product metadata. They investigate various context-aware translation methods, including the use of a vision-language model (VLM) and contextual information in text-to-text models.
AI.result: The study finds that introducing contextual information, such as product categories and image descriptions, significantly enhances translation quality, with visual context showing beneficial effects.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating contextual information into translation models improves translation quality, and the new dataset is made publicly available for further research.
key_contributions: Development of the ConECT dataset for e-commerce translations
Demonstration of the effectiveness of visual context in improving translation
Exploration of integrating contextual information into text-to-text models

title: From Struggle (06-2024) to Mastery (02-2025) LLMs Conquer Advanced Algorithm Exams and Pave the Way for Editorial Generation
comment: 15 pages Pre-print Paper accepted to ITS 2025
summary:
This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the performance of
state-of-the-art Large Language Models (LLMs) on challenging university-level
algorithms exams. By testing multiple models on both a Romanian exam and its
high-quality English translation, we analyze LLMs' problem-solving
capabilities, consistency, and multilingual performance. Our empirical study
reveals that the most recent models not only achieve scores comparable to
top-performing students but also demonstrate robust reasoning skills on
complex, multi-step algorithmic challenges, even though difficulties remain
with graph-based tasks. Building on these findings, we explore the potential of
LLMs to support educational environments through the generation of high-quality
editorial content, offering instructors a powerful tool to enhance student
feedback. The insights and best practices discussed herein pave the way for
further integration of generative AI in advanced algorithm education.

AI.tldr: Evaluation of LLMs on university-level algorithms exams reveals strong reasoning capabilities but challenges in graph-based tasks, proposing potential applications for educational content generation.
AI.motivation: To assess the performance of state-of-the-art Large Language Models (LLMs) on challenging university-level algorithms exams and explore their potential in educational settings.
AI.method: Multiple LLMs were tested on a Romanian algorithms exam and its translated English version, focusing on problem-solving capabilities, consistency, and multilingual performance.
AI.result: Most recent LLMs achieved scores comparable to top-performing students and showed robust reasoning skills on complex algorithmic challenges, with noted difficulties in graph-based tasks.
AI.conclusion: LLMs may significantly enhance educational environments by providing high-quality editorial content for instructor feedback, encouraging further integration of generative AI in advanced algorithm education.
key_contributions: Comprehensive evaluation of LLM performance on university-level exams
Insights into multilingual capabilities of LLMs
Discussion on the educational applications of LLMs for generating content
AI.limitations: Challenges remain with graph-based tasks, which the models struggled with in evaluations.

title: Better Semi-supervised Learning for Multi-domain ASR Through Incremental Retraining and Data Filtering
summary:
Fine-tuning pretrained ASR models for specific domains is challenging when
labeled data is scarce. But unlabeled audio and labeled data from related
domains are often available. We propose an incremental semi-supervised learning
pipeline that first integrates a small in-domain labeled set and an auxiliary
dataset from a closely related domain, achieving a relative improvement of 4%
over no auxiliary data. Filtering based on multi-model consensus or named
entity recognition (NER) is then applied to select and iteratively refine
pseudo-labels, showing slower performance saturation compared to random
selection. Evaluated on the multi-domain Wow call center and Fisher English
corpora, it outperforms single-step fine-tuning. Consensus-based filtering
outperforms other methods, providing up to 22.3% relative improvement on Wow
and 24.8% on Fisher over single-step fine-tuning with random selection. NER is
the second-best filter, providing competitive performance at a lower
computational cost.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an incremental semi-supervised learning pipeline for improving ASR model fine-tuning using auxiliary data and pseudo-labeling techniques.
AI.motivation: Fine-tuning ASR models is difficult in low-data environments; leveraging unlabeled audio and related labeled datasets can enhance performance.
AI.method: An incremental semi-supervised learning approach integrating small in-domain labeled data with an auxiliary dataset from a related domain, applying multi-model consensus and NER for pseudo-label refinement.
AI.result: The proposed method shows performance improvements of up to 24.8% over traditional fine-tuning with rigorous filtering methods.
AI.conclusion: Consensus-based filtering significantly enhances ASR model outcomes, while NER also offers a competitive but less computationally demanding option.
key_contributions: Development of an incremental semi-supervised learning pipeline for ASR models
Demonstration of performance improvements using auxiliary data
Comparison of filtering techniques for pseudo-label refinement in ASR training

title: SCOP: Evaluating the Comprehension Process of Large Language Models from a Cognitive View
comment: arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:2004.14535 by other authors
summary:
Despite the great potential of large language models(LLMs) in machine
comprehension, it is still disturbing to fully count on them in real-world
scenarios. This is probably because there is no rational explanation for
whether the comprehension process of LLMs is aligned with that of experts. In
this paper, we propose SCOP to carefully examine how LLMs perform during the
comprehension process from a cognitive view. Specifically, it is equipped with
a systematical definition of five requisite skills during the comprehension
process, a strict framework to construct testing data for these skills, and a
detailed analysis of advanced open-sourced and closed-sourced LLMs using the
testing data. With SCOP, we find that it is still challenging for LLMs to
perform an expert-level comprehension process. Even so, we notice that LLMs
share some similarities with experts, e.g., performing better at comprehending
local information than global information. Further analysis reveals that LLMs
can be somewhat unreliable -- they might reach correct answers through flawed
comprehension processes. Based on SCOP, we suggest that one direction for
improving LLMs is to focus more on the comprehension process, ensuring all
comprehension skills are thoroughly developed during training.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes SCOP to evaluate the comprehension ability of LLMs against expert-level standards, revealing significant challenges and similarities in their processes.
AI.motivation: To understand whether the comprehension mechanisms of LLMs align with those of human experts and to improve LLM performance.
AI.method: The paper introduces a framework called SCOP, defined by five requisite skills for comprehension, and constructs testing data to analyze various LLMs.
AI.result: LLMs struggle to achieve expert-level comprehension, performing better on local rather than global information, but sometimes providing correct answers with flawed reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Improvement in LLMs should focus on refining the comprehension processes and skill development during training.
key_contributions: Introduction of SCOP framework for evaluating LLM comprehension skills.
Detailed analysis of LLM performance on comprehension tasks.
Identification of similarities and discrepancies between LLM and expert comprehension processes.
AI.limitations: There may be text overlap with previous works, potentially affecting the novelty of findings.

title: ComfyUI-Copilot: An Intelligent Assistant for Automated Workflow Development
summary:
We introduce ComfyUI-Copilot, a large language model-powered plugin designed
to enhance the usability and efficiency of ComfyUI, an open-source platform for
AI-driven art creation. Despite its flexibility and user-friendly interface,
ComfyUI can present challenges to newcomers, including limited documentation,
model misconfigurations, and the complexity of workflow design. ComfyUI-Copilot
addresses these challenges by offering intelligent node and model
recommendations, along with automated one-click workflow construction. At its
core, the system employs a hierarchical multi-agent framework comprising a
central assistant agent for task delegation and specialized worker agents for
different usages, supported by our curated ComfyUI knowledge bases to
streamline debugging and deployment. We validate the effectiveness of
ComfyUI-Copilot through both offline quantitative evaluations and online user
feedback, showing that it accurately recommends nodes and accelerates workflow
development. Additionally, use cases illustrate that ComfyUI-Copilot lowers
entry barriers for beginners and enhances workflow efficiency for experienced
users. The ComfyUI-Copilot installation package and a demo video are available
at https://github.com/AIDC-AI/ComfyUI-Copilot.

AI.tldr: ComfyUI-Copilot is a plugin that enhances ComfyUI by providing intelligent recommendations and automated workflow construction, making it accessible for newcomers and efficient for experienced users.
AI.motivation: To improve usability for newcomers and enhance efficiency for experienced users of ComfyUI, an open-source platform for AI-driven art creation.
AI.method: A hierarchical multi-agent framework with a central assistant agent for task delegation and specialized worker agents for various uses, backed by curated knowledge bases.
AI.result: ComfyUI-Copilot accurately recommends nodes and accelerates workflow development, validated through offline evaluations and user feedback.
AI.conclusion: ComfyUI-Copilot lowers entry barriers for beginners and enhances workflow efficiency for experienced users.
key_contributions: Intelligent node and model recommendations
Automated one-click workflow construction
Hierarchical multi-agent framework for task delegation

title: Controlling Summarization Length Through EOS Token Weighting
summary:
Controlling the length of generated text can be crucial in various
text-generation tasks, including summarization. Existing methods often require
complex model alterations, limiting compatibility with pre-trained models. We
address these limitations by developing a simple approach for controlling the
length of automatic text summaries by increasing the importance of correctly
predicting the EOS token in the cross-entropy loss computation. The proposed
methodology is agnostic to architecture and decoding algorithms and orthogonal
to other inference-time techniques to control the generation length. We tested
it with encoder-decoder and modern GPT-style LLMs, and show that this method
can control generation length, often without affecting the quality of the
summary.

AI.tldr: A method for controlling text generation length by focusing on EOS token prediction without altering model architectures.
AI.motivation: The need for simpler length control methods in text generation tasks like summarization that are compatible with pre-trained models.
AI.method: Increased the importance of predicting the EOS token in the cross-entropy loss computation to control generated text length.
AI.result: The method effectively controls text generation length using various architectures and decoding algorithms, maintaining summary quality.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method allows for effective length control in text generation while remaining compatible with existing models and techniques.
key_contributions: Simple approach for length control in text generation
Compatibility with various model architectures
Maintains summary quality during length control

title: Automatic Robustness Stress Testing of LLMs as Mathematical Problem Solvers
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have achieved distinguished performance on
various reasoning-intensive tasks. However, LLMs might still face the
challenges of robustness issues and fail unexpectedly in some simple reasoning
tasks. Previous works evaluate the LLM robustness with hand-crafted templates
or a limited set of perturbation rules, indicating potential data contamination
in pre-training or fine-tuning datasets. In this work, inspired by stress
testing in software engineering, we propose a novel framework, Automatic
Robustness Checker (AR-Checker), to generate mathematical problem variants that
maintain the semantic meanings of the original one but might fail the LLMs. The
AR-Checker framework generates mathematical problem variants through
multi-round parallel streams of LLM-based rewriting and verification. Our
framework can generate benchmark variants dynamically for each LLM, thus
minimizing the risk of data contamination. Experiments on GSM8K and MATH-500
demonstrate the strong performance of AR-Checker on mathematical tasks. We also
evaluate AR-Checker on benchmarks beyond mathematics, including MMLU, MMLU-Pro,
and CommonsenseQA, where it also achieves strong performance, further proving
the effectiveness of AR-Checker.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes the AR-Checker framework to assess and improve the robustness of large language models (LLMs) on reasoning tasks by generating variation in mathematical problems.
AI.motivation: To address robustness issues in LLMs that lead to failures in simple reasoning tasks and mitigate potential data contamination in training datasets.
AI.method: The AR-Checker generates mathematical problem variants through LLM-based rewriting and verification, using a multi-round parallel approach to dynamically create benchmarks that reduce risks of data contamination.
AI.result: Experiments show that AR-Checker performs strongly on mathematical tasks using GSM8K and MATH-500, and also demonstrates strong performance on diverse benchmarks like MMLU, MMLU-Pro, and CommonsenseQA.
AI.conclusion: The AR-Checker framework effectively enhances the robustness assessment of LLMs on reasoning tasks through dynamically generated problem variants, proving its versatility across various benchmarks.
key_contributions: Introduction of the AR-Checker framework for LLM robustness evaluation
Dynamic generation of problem variants to prevent data contamination
Strong empirical results across multiple benchmarks in mathematics and beyond

title: TALL -- A Trainable Architecture for Enhancing LLM Performance in Low-Resource Languages
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) excel in high-resource languages but struggle
with low-resource languages due to limited training data. This paper presents
TALL (Trainable Architecture for Enhancing LLM Performance in Low-Resource
Languages), which integrates an LLM with two bilingual translation models. TALL
transforms low-resource inputs into high-resource representations, leveraging
the LLM's capabilities while preserving linguistic features through dimension
alignment layers and custom transformers. Our experiments on Hebrew demonstrate
significant improvements over several baselines, including direct use, naive
translation, and fine-tuning approaches. The architecture employs a
parameter-efficient strategy, freezing pre-trained components while training
only lightweight adapter modules, balancing computational efficiency with
performance gains.

AI.tldr: TALL is a new architecture that enhances LLM performance for low-resource languages by leveraging bilingual translation models to transform inputs into higher-resource representations while maintaining linguistic features.
AI.motivation: This paper addresses the challenge that Large Language Models (LLMs) face in low-resource languages where abundant training data is not available, leading to performance issues.
AI.method: TALL integrates an LLM with two bilingual translation models to convert low-resource inputs into high-resource representations, using dimension alignment layers and custom transformers to preserve linguistic characteristics.
AI.result: Experiments conducted on Hebrew show significant performance improvements of TALL compared to several baselines, including naive translation and fine-tuning methods.
AI.conclusion: TALL achieves a balance between computational efficiency and improved performance in low-resource language settings through a parameter-efficient strategy.
key_contributions: Introducing TALL, a novel architecture for low-resource language processing.
Integration of bilingual translation models with LLMs.
Parameter-efficient training strategy with lightweight adapter modules.

title: Debatable Intelligence: Benchmarking LLM Judges via Debate Speech Evaluation
summary:
We introduce Debate Speech Evaluation as a novel and challenging benchmark
for assessing LLM judges. Evaluating debate speeches requires a deep
understanding of the speech at multiple levels, including argument strength and
relevance, the coherence and organization of the speech, the appropriateness of
its style and tone, and so on. This task involves a unique set of cognitive
abilities that have previously received limited attention in systematic LLM
benchmarking. To explore such skills, we leverage a dataset of over 600
meticulously annotated debate speeches and present the first in-depth analysis
of how state-of-the-art LLMs compare to human judges on this task. Our findings
reveal a nuanced picture: while larger models can approximate individual human
judgments in some respects, they differ substantially in their overall judgment
behavior. We also investigate the ability of frontier LLMs to generate
persuasive, opinionated speeches, showing that models may perform at a human
level on this task.

AI.tldr: Presentation of Debate Speech Evaluation as a benchmark for assessing LLM judging capabilities and comparison with human judges.
AI.motivation: To evaluate LLM judges' performance in assessing debate speeches, which involves complex cognitive abilities that have not been systematically benchmarked.
AI.method: Leveraged a dataset of over 600 annotated debate speeches to analyze LLMs compared to human judges.
AI.result: Larger models approximate human judgments in certain aspects, but differ in overall judgment behavior. LLMs can generate persuasive speeches at a human level.
AI.conclusion: The findings indicate nuanced differences between LLMs and human evaluators in debate speech assessments.
key_contributions: Introduction of Debate Speech Evaluation benchmark
Comparison of LLMs and human judges in evaluating debate speeches
Analysis of LLMs' ability to generate opinionated speeches

title: Does It Make Sense to Speak of Introspection in Large Language Models?
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) exhibit compelling linguistic behaviour, and
sometimes offer self-reports, that is to say statements about their own nature,
inner workings, or behaviour. In humans, such reports are often attributed to a
faculty of introspection and are typically linked to consciousness. This raises
the question of how to interpret self-reports produced by LLMs, given their
increasing linguistic fluency and cognitive capabilities. To what extent (if
any) can the concept of introspection be meaningfully applied to LLMs? Here, we
present and critique two examples of apparent introspective self-report from
LLMs. In the first example, an LLM attempts to describe the process behind its
own ``creative'' writing, and we argue this is not a valid example of
introspection. In the second example, an LLM correctly infers the value of its
own temperature parameter, and we argue that this can be legitimately
considered a minimal example of introspection, albeit one that is (presumably)
not accompanied by conscious experience.

AI.tldr: The paper critiques self-reports from large language models (LLMs) related to introspection, presenting two examples to explore the applicability of introspection in LLMs.
AI.motivation: To explore and critique the validity of introspection as it applies to the self-reports generated by large language models (LLMs), particularly in relation to their linguistic fluency and cognitive abilities.
AI.method: The paper analyzes and critiques two specific self-reports from LLMs: one regarding the creative writing process and another about the LLM's temperature parameter.
AI.result: The study concludes that the first example of self-report related to creative writing is not valid introspection, while the second example regarding the temperature parameter can be regarded as a minimal form of introspection without conscious experience.
AI.conclusion: The concept of introspection can be applied to LLMs to a limited extent, highlighting important distinctions between valid self-reports and those that are not reflective of true introspective capabilities.
key_contributions: Critique of LLMs' introspective claims
Differentiation between valid and invalid self-reports
Exploration of LLM consciousness and introspection concept.

title: RIVAL: Reinforcement Learning with Iterative and Adversarial Optimization for Machine Translation
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) possess strong multilingual capabilities, and
combining Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) with translation
tasks has shown great potential. However, we observe that this paradigm
performs unexpectedly poorly when applied to colloquial subtitle translation
tasks. In this work, we investigate this issue and find that the offline reward
model (RM) gradually diverges from the online LLM due to distributional shift,
ultimately leading to undesirable training outcomes. To address this, we
propose RIVAL, an adversarial training framework that formulates the process as
a min-max game between the RM and the LLM. RIVAL iteratively updates the both
models, with the RM trained to distinguish strong from weak translations
(qualitative preference reward), and the LLM trained to enhance its translation
for closing this gap. To stabilize training and improve generalizability, we
also incorporate quantitative preference reward (e.g., BLEU) into the RM,
enabling reference-free quality modeling aligned with human evaluation. Through
extensive experiments, we demonstrate that the proposed adversarial training
framework significantly improves upon translation baselines.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces RIVAL, an adversarial training framework for improving translation tasks in large language models (LLMs), addressing the challenges encountered in colloquial subtitle translation due to distributional shifts in reward models.
AI.motivation: Large language models struggle with translation tasks, especially colloquial subtitles, due to a divergence between offline reward models and online LLMs caused by distributional shifts.
AI.method: RIVAL formulates the training process as a min-max game, where the reward model (RM) distinguishes strong from weak translations, while the LLM improves its translations to bridge the gap. It incorporates both qualitative and quantitative preference rewards into the RM.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that RIVAL significantly outperforms existing translation baselines, leading to better performance in colloquial subtitle translation tasks.
AI.conclusion: The adversarial training framework presented in RIVAL helps mitigate issues related to distributional shifts, enhancing the generalizability and stability of translation tasks for LLMs.
key_contributions: Introduced RIVAL, an adversarial training framework for LLMs in translation tasks
Demonstrated significant improvement in colloquial subtitle translation
Integrated qualitative and quantitative rewards into the training process

title: Just a Scratch: Enhancing LLM Capabilities for Self-harm Detection through Intent Differentiation and Emoji Interpretation
comment:
To be published in the Proceedings of the 63rd Annual Meeting of the
  Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL 2025 Main)
summary:
Self-harm detection on social media is critical for early intervention and
mental health support, yet remains challenging due to the subtle,
context-dependent nature of such expressions. Identifying self-harm intent aids
suicide prevention by enabling timely responses, but current large language
models (LLMs) struggle to interpret implicit cues in casual language and
emojis. This work enhances LLMs' comprehension of self-harm by distinguishing
intent through nuanced language-emoji interplay. We present the Centennial
Emoji Sensitivity Matrix (CESM-100), a curated set of 100 emojis with
contextual self-harm interpretations and the Self-Harm Identification aNd
intent Extraction with Supportive emoji sensitivity (SHINES) dataset, offering
detailed annotations for self-harm labels, casual mentions (CMs), and serious
intents (SIs). Our unified framework: a) enriches inputs using CESM-100; b)
fine-tunes LLMs for multi-task learning: self-harm detection (primary) and
CM/SI span detection (auxiliary); c) generates explainable rationales for
self-harm predictions. We evaluate the framework on three state-of-the-art
LLMs-Llama 3, Mental-Alpaca, and MentalLlama, across zero-shot, few-shot, and
fine-tuned scenarios. By coupling intent differentiation with contextual cues,
our approach commendably enhances LLM performance in both detection and
explanation tasks, effectively addressing the inherent ambiguity in self-harm
signals. The SHINES dataset, CESM-100 and codebase are publicly available at:
https://www.iitp.ac.in/~ai-nlp-ml/resources.html#SHINES .

AI.tldr: This paper enhances large language models' ability to detect self-harm on social media through a new framework that uses contextual emoji interpretations and multi-task learning.
AI.motivation: The challenge of detecting self-harm intent in social media posts amidst nuanced language and emoji usage necessitates improved model understanding for timely mental health interventions.
AI.method: A unified framework that utilizes the Centennial Emoji Sensitivity Matrix (CESM-100) and fine-tunes large language models for self-harm detection and intent differentiation through multi-task learning.
AI.result: The framework significantly improves the performance of Llama 3, Mental-Alpaca, and MentalLlama in detecting self-harm through better interpretation of casual language and emoji context.
AI.conclusion: By enhancing intent differentiation and contextual understanding, the proposed framework effectively increases LLM performance in detecting self-harm, allowing for actionable insights in mental health support.
key_contributions: Introduction of CESM-100 for emoji context in self-harm detection.
Development of the SHINES dataset with detailed annotations for self-harm identification.
A multi-task learning framework that generates explainable rationales for predictions.
AI.limitations: Current evaluation focuses on state-of-the-art LLMs; further testing on other models may be needed to verify generalizability.

title: Parking, Perception, and Retail: Street-Level Determinants of Community Vitality in Harbin
summary:
The commercial vitality of community-scale streets in Chinese cities is
shaped by complex interactions between vehicular accessibility, environmental
quality, and pedestrian perception. This study proposes an interpretable,
image-based framework to examine how street-level features -- including parked
vehicle density, greenery, cleanliness, and street width -- impact retail
performance and user satisfaction in Harbin, China. Leveraging street view
imagery and a multimodal large language model (VisualGLM-6B), we construct a
Community Commercial Vitality Index (CCVI) from Meituan and Dianping data and
analyze its relationship with spatial attributes extracted via GPT-4-based
perception modeling. Our findings reveal that while moderate vehicle presence
may enhance commercial access, excessive on-street parking -- especially in
narrow streets -- erodes walkability and reduces both satisfaction and
shop-level pricing. In contrast, streets with higher perceived greenery and
cleanliness show significantly greater satisfaction scores but only weak
associations with pricing. Street width moderates the effects of vehicle
presence, underscoring the importance of spatial configuration. These results
demonstrate the value of integrating AI-assisted perception with urban
morphological analysis to capture non-linear and context-sensitive drivers of
commercial success. This study advances both theoretical and methodological
frontiers by highlighting the conditional role of vehicle activity in
neighborhood commerce and demonstrating the feasibility of multimodal AI for
perceptual urban diagnostics. The implications extend to urban design, parking
management, and scalable planning tools for community revitalization.

AI.tldr: This paper develops an interpretable framework to assess how street-level features affect retail performance and user satisfaction in Harbin, China, using AI-assisted methods and urban morphological analysis.
AI.motivation: To understand the impact of street features on the commercial vitality of community-scale streets in Chinese cities.
AI.method: The study utilizes street view imagery and a multimodal large language model (VisualGLM-6B) to create a Community Commercial Vitality Index (CCVI) and examines associations with spatial attributes through GPT-4-based perception modeling.
AI.result: Findings indicate that moderate vehicle presence can enhance commercial access, while excessive parking reduces walkability and satisfaction. Increased greenery and cleanliness improve satisfaction but have weak pricing associations. Street width moderates vehicle impact on commerce.
AI.conclusion: The research highlights the conditional role of vehicle activity in neighborhood commerce and validates the integration of AI in urban diagnostics, impacting urban design and planning.
key_contributions: Introduces the Community Commercial Vitality Index (CCVI)
Demonstrates the use of AI-assisted perception for analyzing urban features
Explores the complexity of vehicle accessibility and its effects on commercial success

title: CL-ISR: A Contrastive Learning and Implicit Stance Reasoning Framework for Misleading Text Detection on Social Media
summary:
Misleading text detection on social media platforms is a critical research
area, as these texts can lead to public misunderstanding, social panic and even
economic losses. This paper proposes a novel framework - CL-ISR (Contrastive
Learning and Implicit Stance Reasoning), which combines contrastive learning
and implicit stance reasoning, to improve the detection accuracy of misleading
texts on social media. First, we use the contrastive learning algorithm to
improve the model's learning ability of semantic differences between truthful
and misleading texts. Contrastive learning could help the model to better
capture the distinguishing features between different categories by
constructing positive and negative sample pairs. This approach enables the
model to capture distinguishing features more effectively, particularly in
linguistically complicated situations. Second, we introduce the implicit stance
reasoning module, to explore the potential stance tendencies in the text and
their relationships with related topics. This method is effective for
identifying content that misleads through stance shifting or emotional
manipulation, because it can capture the implicit information behind the text.
Finally, we integrate these two algorithms together to form a new framework,
CL-ISR, which leverages the discriminative power of contrastive learning and
the interpretive depth of stance reasoning to significantly improve detection
effect.

AI.tldr: This paper presents CL-ISR, a novel framework for detecting misleading texts on social media using contrastive learning and implicit stance reasoning.
AI.motivation: Misleading texts on social media can cause public misunderstanding, panic, and economic losses, making accurate detection crucial.
AI.method: The framework combines contrastive learning to enhance semantic understanding with an implicit stance reasoning module to identify subtle manipulation in texts.
AI.result: CL-ISR significantly improves detection accuracy by effectively capturing semantic differences and implicit information behind misleading texts.
AI.conclusion: Integrating contrastive learning with stance reasoning advances the capability of models to discern misleading content more effectively.
key_contributions: Proposes CL-ISR framework for misleading text detection
Implements contrastive learning to enhance feature distinction
Introduces implicit stance reasoning to analyze emotional manipulation

title: The NTNU System at the S&I Challenge 2025 SLA Open Track
comment: submitted to the ISCA SLaTE-2025 Workshop
summary:
A recent line of research on spoken language assessment (SLA) employs neural
models such as BERT and wav2vec 2.0 (W2V) to evaluate speaking proficiency
across linguistic and acoustic modalities. Although both models effectively
capture features relevant to oral competence, each exhibits modality-specific
limitations. BERT-based methods rely on ASR transcripts, which often fail to
capture prosodic and phonetic cues for SLA. In contrast, W2V-based methods
excel at modeling acoustic features but lack semantic interpretability. To
overcome these limitations, we propose a system that integrates W2V with Phi-4
multimodal large language model (MLLM) through a score fusion strategy. The
proposed system achieves a root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.375 on the
official test set of the Speak & Improve Challenge 2025, securing second place
in the competition. For comparison, the RMSEs of the top-ranked, third-ranked,
and official baseline systems are 0.364, 0.384, and 0.444, respectively.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a multimodal system integrating W2V and Phi-4 MLLM for spoken language assessment, achieving competitive RMSE results in evaluation tasks.
AI.motivation: To address limitations in spoken language assessment using neural models, focusing on capturing both acoustic features and semantic interpretability.
AI.method: The system integrates wav2vec 2.0 (W2V) with a multimodal large language model (MLLM) through a score fusion strategy.
AI.result: The proposed system achieved an RMSE of 0.375, outperforming the official baseline and securing second place in the Speak & Improve Challenge 2025.
AI.conclusion: The integration of W2V and Phi-4 MLLM provides an effective approach for spoken language assessment, balancing acoustic modeling and semantic interpretation.
key_contributions: Integration of W2V with Phi-4 MLLM for SLA
Score fusion strategy to enhance assessment accuracy
Competitive performance in a benchmark challenge

title: DiCoRe: Enhancing Zero-shot Event Detection via Divergent-Convergent LLM Reasoning
summary:
Zero-shot Event Detection (ED), the task of identifying event mentions in
natural language text without any training data, is critical for document
understanding in specialized domains. Understanding the complex event ontology,
extracting domain-specific triggers from the passage, and structuring them
appropriately overloads and limits the utility of Large Language Models (LLMs)
for zero-shot ED. To this end, we propose DiCoRe, a divergent-convergent
reasoning framework that decouples the task of ED using Dreamer and Grounder.
Dreamer encourages divergent reasoning through open-ended event discovery,
which helps to boost event coverage. Conversely, Grounder introduces convergent
reasoning to align the free-form predictions with the task-specific
instructions using finite-state machine guided constrained decoding.
Additionally, an LLM-Judge verifies the final outputs to ensure high precision.
Through extensive experiments on six datasets across five domains and nine
LLMs, we demonstrate how DiCoRe consistently outperforms prior zero-shot,
transfer-learning, and reasoning baselines, achieving 4-7% average F1 gains
over the best baseline -- establishing DiCoRe as a strong zero-shot ED
framework.

AI.tldr: DiCoRe is a framework for zero-shot Event Detection (ED) that enhances performance by decoupling event discovery and alignment processes using divergent and convergent reasoning.
AI.motivation: There is a need for effective zero-shot Event Detection in specialized domains without training data, yet current methods struggle with complex event ontology and trigger extraction.
AI.method: DiCoRe employs a divergent-convergent reasoning framework, where Dreamer supports divergent event discovery and Grounder aligns predictions with task instructions through constrained decoding and verification by an LLM-Judge.
AI.result: DiCoRe demonstrated 4-7% average F1 score gains over the best existing methods across six datasets and five domains, proving its effectiveness in zero-shot ED.
AI.conclusion: DiCoRe establishes itself as a strong framework for zero-shot Event Detection, significantly improving performance and reliability in this task.
key_contributions: Introduction of a divergent-convergent reasoning framework for ED
Utilization of an LLM-Judge for output verification
Demonstrated performance improvement over existing baselines in zero-shot ED.

title: Information Locality as an Inductive Bias for Neural Language Models
summary:
Inductive biases are inherent in every machine learning system, shaping how
models generalize from finite data. In the case of neural language models
(LMs), debates persist as to whether these biases align with or diverge from
human processing constraints. To address this issue, we propose a quantitative
framework that allows for controlled investigations into the nature of these
biases. Within our framework, we introduce $m$-local entropy$\unicode{x2013}$an
information-theoretic measure derived from average lossy-context
surprisal$\unicode{x2013}$that captures the local uncertainty of a language by
quantifying how effectively the $m-1$ preceding symbols disambiguate the next
symbol. In experiments on both perturbed natural language corpora and languages
defined by probabilistic finite-state automata (PFSAs), we show that languages
with higher $m$-local entropy are more difficult for Transformer and LSTM LMs
to learn. These results suggest that neural LMs, much like humans, are highly
sensitive to the local statistical structure of a language.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a framework using $m$-local entropy to investigate inductive biases in language models and their alignment with human processing constraints.
AI.motivation: To explore the nature of inductive biases in neural language models and their relationship with human language processing.
AI.method: The authors introduce $m$-local entropy, an information-theoretic measure related to average lossy-context surprisal, to quantify local uncertainty in languages and assess how well preceding symbols disambiguate subsequent symbols.
AI.result: Higher $m$-local entropy in languages correlates with increased difficulty for Transformer and LSTM language models to learn these languages.
AI.conclusion: Neural language models exhibit sensitivity to the local statistical structures of language, paralleling human cognitive processing patterns.
key_contributions: Introduction of the $m$-local entropy measure for analyzing language models.
Experimental validation on natural language corpora and languages defined by probabilistic finite-state automata.
Insights into the relationship between inductive biases in neural LMs and human language processing.

title: AudioLens: A Closer Look at Auditory Attribute Perception of Large Audio-Language Models
summary:
Understanding the internal mechanisms of large audio-language models (LALMs)
is crucial for interpreting their behavior and improving performance. This work
presents the first in-depth analysis of how LALMs internally perceive and
recognize auditory attributes. By applying vocabulary projection on three
state-of-the-art LALMs, we track how attribute information evolves across
layers and token positions. We find that attribute information generally
decreases with layer depth when recognition fails, and that resolving
attributes at earlier layers correlates with better accuracy. Moreover, LALMs
heavily rely on querying auditory inputs for predicting attributes instead of
aggregating necessary information in hidden states at attribute-mentioning
positions. Based on our findings, we demonstrate a method to enhance LALMs. Our
results offer insights into auditory attribute processing, paving the way for
future improvements.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes how large audio-language models (LALMs) process and recognize auditory attributes, revealing insights into their internal mechanisms and proposing methods for performance enhancement.
AI.motivation: Understanding the internal mechanisms of LALMs is crucial for interpreting their behavior and improving performance in audio and language processing tasks.
AI.method: The authors apply vocabulary projection on three state-of-the-art LALMs to track the evolution of attribute information across layers and token positions.
AI.result: The study finds that recognition of auditory attributes generally declines with layer depth, and early resolution of attributes correlates with better model performance. It also shows that LALMs rely more on querying auditory inputs than on using hidden states for attribute prediction.
AI.conclusion: The findings enhance understanding of auditory attribute processing in LALMs and propose methods for improving their performance.
key_contributions: First in-depth analysis of LALMs' auditory perception
Identification of layer depth's impact on attribute recognition
Proposing methods to enhance LALM performance based on findings

title: Do Large Language Models Judge Error Severity Like Humans?
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly used as automated evaluators in
natural language generation, yet it remains unclear whether they can accurately
